conclusion: The problem involves an ideal gas undergoing a process from state A to state B, with given conditions, and requires using thermodynamics principles to find the heat absorbed.
The graph shows the relationship between volume (V) and temperature (T) for an ideal gas. Line segment AB is parallel to the V-axis, and the extension of BC passes through the origin.
At state A, the volume \( V_A = V_0 \) and the temperature \( T_A = T_0 \). At state B, the volume \( V_B = 2V_0 \) and the temperature \( T_B = T_0 \).
The work done by the gas on the outside world during the process from state A to state B is given as 10 J.
The work done by the gas is calculated using the formula \( W = p \Delta V \), where \( p \) is the pressure and \( \Delta V \) is the change in volume.
Since \( pA = p0 \) and \( \Delta V = V_B - V_A = 2V_0 - V_0 = V_0 \), the work done is \( 10 = p0 \times V_0 \).
From the equation \( 10 = p0 \times V_0 \), the pressure \( p0 \) is calculated as \( p0 = \frac{10}{V_0} \).
The heat absorbed by the gas is equal to the work done by the gas on the outside world, \( Q = W = 10 \, \text{J} \).
Since the heat absorbed by the gas is equal to the work done by the gas on the outside world, the heat absorbed is 10 J.
